awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Optimal Sensor Selection and Robust Traffic Detection and Estimation in a World of Connected Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
Reliable traffic management strategies require accurate knowledge of traffic levels on roads. Though the emergence of connected vehicles (CV) offers tremendous potential for sharing traffic data about vehicles' locations and speeds through wireless communications, there are both privacy concerns and bandwidth constraints - not all users want to share and not all vehicles are able to share. This project will address both issues by designing methods to guide the selection of some road users for data sharing and analysis to provide accurate estimation of traffic levels in real time, while addressing privacy and bandwidth issues. Throughout this project, training modules in  traffic and machine learning sciences will be designed at both UT San Antonio and UT Austin and students from underrepresented groups will be recruited at UTSA where 58 percent of enrolled students are minorities.

The project will: (i) consider privacy of user data hence maintaining anonymity of vehicles and users, (ii) identify sudden changes in traffic conditions due to accidents, (iii) design a time-varying selection of traffic data collected in real-time from CVs, and (iv) quantify limits on the network bandwidth and uncertainty in traffic conditions and road properties. The project's major contribution lies in advancing the use of CVs as real-time, mobile traffic sensors. This involves the integration of concepts from multiple disciplines: traffic flow, networked systems, estimation, and machine learning theories. Specifically, the project will investigate computationally scalable methods that traffic operators can utilize to optimally sample data from CVs while satisfying privacy and bandwidth constraints, thereby monitoring traffic in real-time. The theoretical foundations will be validated with realistic traffic setups through collaborations with the cities of Austin and San Antonio. The broader impact of the research transcends traffic networks: the computational algorithms will be applicable to related problems involving networked systems of partial differential equations and moving sensing platforms such as environmental monitoring by robot and unmanned aerial vehicles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With an ever-growing population center, traffic congestion has become a major issue in most areas of the world. One of the most inexpensive ways to address traffic congestion is through computational algorithms. These algorithms better control traffic via ramp traffic lights or meters and dynamic speed limits that change in peak traffic conditions. These traffic control algorithms and their performance are highly dependent on the accuracy of the traffic state data that informs the algorithms’ operation. In short, reliable traffic management strategies require accurate knowledge of traffic levels or densities on roads. To that end, the emergence of connected vehicles (CV) offers tremendous potential for sharing traffic data about vehicles' locations and speeds through wireless communication and advanced 5G networks. The utilization of such networks poses its own challenges for traffic and congestion monitoring and control: there are both privacy concerns and bandwidth constraints when utilizing such wireless networks. Not all users want to share their data with a traffic operator and many vehicles are unable to share due to limited connectivity or bandwidth constraints.

 

 

This project addresses both issues by designing methods to guide the selection of some road users for data sharing and analysis to provide accurate estimation of traffic levels in real time, while addressing privacy and bandwidth issues. The outcome of this project is a set of algorithms that address the following question: How can traffic operators optimally sample data from legacy traffic sensors and CVs while satisfying privacy and bandwidth constraints, thereby monitoring traffic in real time?

 

To address the above research question, we leverage the classical advanced versions of the cell transmission model (CTM) that describes the evolution of traffic density and flux in transportation networks. This model forms a nonlinear dynamic network modeling traffic flow---a network model that explicitly incorporates uncertainty due to natural or malicious adversities, because of traffic networks becoming highly reliant on wireless communications. Furthermore, traffic dynamics are naturally hybrid as mode changes (i.e., congested and uncongested modes) of highway traffic occur frequently.

 

 

Utilizing the CTM and its many variants, we achieve the following five project outcomes.

 

  • Outcome 1: Given the uncertain, hybrid dynamics, the first outcome of this project is a set of algorithms that solve the following coupled problems: (i) The fixed and time-varying placement/selection of different types of traffic sensors and CVs. (ii) Real-time detection of highway congestion mode changes through new machine learning algorithms. (iii) Robust traffic estimation that is robust to worst-case uncertainty from road closures, erroneous traffic data, and potential cyber-attacks. Solving the joint decision-making problems (i)--(iii) results in a better state estimate of traffic, which in turn can be used for more accurate control of the network, while allowing CV trips to remain private, and minimizing the bandwidth requirements.

 

  • Outcome 2: The second outcome of the project is to scale the above algorithms to large-scale networks through efficient computational methods. We achieve that via efficient convex optimization and semidefinite program algorithms. We demonstrate the impact of these algorithms on large-scale traffic networks via detailed case studies.

 

  • Outcome 3: The third outcome is to incorporate privacy constraints into the above Outcomes 1-2, when dealing with CV-generated, privacy-sensitive data. This also enables evaluating the price of privacy in terms of information loss for traffic state estimation purposes.

 

  • Outcome 4: The fourth outcome is a thorough validation of the proposed theoretical foundations on realistic traffic data and networks. The impact of the proposed research transcends traffic networks.

 

  • Outcome 5: The fifth and final project outcome investigates problems that are adjacent to sensing, state estimation, and sensor placement in transportation networks. We expanded the scope of this project to include problems related CV-based traffic control to mitigate bottlenecks via a control-theoretic approach and CV stability problems. Case studies are also conducted on the TransModeler traffic microsimulation software to test the usability of the proposed controllers and stability-ensuring methods as well as other existing controllers in a realistic setting and derive qualitative insights. It is observed that the proposed controller works well in both settings to mitigate the impact of the jam caused by a fixed bottleneck. The computation time required by the controller is also small, making it suitable for real-time control.

 

 

The impact of the key findings from this project will enable transportation system operator to find optimal locations of sensors to install on highways. Furthermore, it will allow system operator to optimally sample specific CAVs to share data from. This will improve the visibility and observability of transportation system operators, and hence enable more realistic real-time feedback ramp metering control. The created research from this project also has an impact in the fields of control theory (sensor placement theory herein can be extended to other dynamic systems), statistical point change detection and signal processing.
